contentrichtext.text: '''Joyce Young''' (born c. 1925) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] woman famous for a single act of [[philanthropy]]. She is the wife of Bill Young, a retired [[Major (Canada)|Major]] in the [[Canadian Armed Forces]] and the aunt of [[Red Hat|Red Hat, Inc.]] founder [[Bob Young (businessman)|Bob Young]]. ==Early Life== Bill Young graduated from [[Hillfield Strathallan College]] in 1935 and Joyce graduated from Hillfield in 1943. After graduating, Bill served in the Canadian military during [[World War II]], serving in [[England]], [[Italy]], and northwest Europe. The couple met after Bill returned from the war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hillstrath.on.ca/news-room/publications/hillstrath-review/HSReview_Winter%202004.pdf |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071020133253/http://www.hillstrath.on.ca/news-room/publications/hillstrath-review/HSReview_Winter%202004.pdf |archivedate=October 20, 2007 |title=Deep Roots |publisher=Hillstrath Review |volume=4 |date=Fall 2004 |page=6}}</ref> Joyce left [[The University of Toronto]] to become a full-time home-maker. The couple have three children, Douglas, Catherine, and William. ==Red Hat, Inc.== Young and her husband Bill Young, both residents of [[Ancaster, Ontario]],<ref name=jyoung>{{cite web |url=http://www.hcf.on.ca/pages/news/newsarchive/2001/youngfund.htm |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930105411/http://www.hcf.on.ca/pages/news/newsarchive/2001/youngfund.htm |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |title=A Gift With Potential To Transform - The Young Fund |publisher=Hamilton Community Foundation News |date=Spring 2000}}</ref> opted to help their nephew Bob with his high-tech venture shortly after its founding in 1993. Bob's company, Red Hat, Inc., is one dedicated to open source software such as [[Red Hat Linux]], and the proprietary [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]]. When Red Hat's stock rose significantly after its [[initial public offering]] in 1999, the elder Youngs were able to sell enough [[stock]] to recoup their initial investment, but chose to retain some stocks. Joyce was quoted as saying {{quote|"While I respect Bob as a businessman, I quite honestly never thought I'd see my money again. I really just wanted to support him. After holding the company's stock for three years, I took out my original investment, and left some money in just for fun."}} By January 2000, the remaining stock was valued in millions. This enabled Joyce to make a donation of [[Canadian dollar|CAD$]]40 million in June 2000, to the [[Hamilton Community Foundation]]. The money was given for the purpose of improving [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]]-area health facilities. This act that represented one of the largest charitable donations in Canadian history. A long-time [[volunteer]] with local community groups, she later stated her biggest concern was in giving away the money responsibly. ==Projects== * $50,000 was donated to Hillfield Strathallan College. * $50,000 was donated for the beautification of the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] Memorial Arch.<ref name=grants>{{cite web |url=http://www.hcf.on.ca/pages/grants/donoradvised/donoradvised01_02.htm#twentyone |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20050505140445/http://www.hcf.on.ca/pages/grants/donoradvised/donoradvised01_02.htm#twentyone |archivedate=May 5, 2005 |title=Grants 2001-2002 |publisher=Hamilton Community Foundation}}</ref> * $50,000 was donated to the [[Juno Beach Centre]].<ref name=grants/> Established by 2552 Major (Ret'd) Bill Young (RMC 1936) and Joyce Young, the ''J.D. Young Memorial lecture'', a speech given at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]], as well as other activities by the ''[[Honorary title (academic)|Young Memorial Visitor]]'', honour the memories of 2360 Major John Douglas (Doug) Young (RMC 1937) who was [[killed in action]] on [[D-Day]], and his father, Maj.-Gen. James V. Young (RMC 1911).
